title: Fake Microsoft Virus Warning
subject: Windows Defender - CRITICAL ALERT
body:
üî¥ CRITICAL SECURITY WARNING üî¥

Windows Defender has detected (3) viruses on your computer!

Threat: Trojan.Malware.300983.susgen
Status: ACTIVE ‚Äî Your personal data is AT RISK

‚ö†Ô∏è DO NOT TURN OFF YOUR COMPUTER ‚ö†Ô∏è

Your bank passwords, credit card numbers, and personal photos may be compromised.

Call Microsoft Certified Technicians IMMEDIATELY:
üìû 1-800-555-0199
(Toll Free ‚Äî Available 24/7)

Error Code: DW6VB36
redFlags: Microsoft NEVER displays phone numbers in security warnings
Real antivirus alerts don't appear as browser pop-ups with phone numbers
Designed to look like Windows but appears in a web browser
Scare tactics ‚Äî 'bank passwords and photos compromised'
Tells you not to turn off your computer (to keep you on the scam page)
Fake error code makes it seem technical and legitimate
explanation: This is the 'tech support scam' ‚Äî one of the most profitable scams targeting seniors. The pop-up appears while browsing and cannot be closed easily, making it seem like a real system alert. If you call the number, scammers will convince you to install remote access software (like AnyDesk or TeamViewer), then 'show' you fake problems on your computer. They'll charge $200-$500 for 'repairs' and may also steal personal files and banking info. Real Windows alerts never show phone numbers. Close the browser (Ctrl+Alt+Delete if needed) and ignore it.
howToSpot: Real antivirus alerts never include phone numbers. Security warnings that appear in your web browser are always fake. Close the browser if you see one. Microsoft will never ask you to call a phone number.

title: Fake Apple Security Warning
subject: Apple Security Alert
body:
‚ö†Ô∏è YOUR APPLE ID HAS BEEN COMPROMISED ‚ö†Ô∏è

Someone in Russia is trying to access your Apple ID!

Your iCloud photos, messages, and Apple Pay are at risk.

Do NOT close this window ‚Äî your device is currently being protected.

Contact Apple Support immediately to secure your account:
üìû 1-855-555-0134

Apple Support
Case ID: APL-2025-88743
redFlags: Apple NEVER shows security alerts as browser pop-ups
Real Apple security notifications appear in your Settings app or via email from @apple.com
Phone number is fake ‚Äî Apple's real support is at support.apple.com
Telling you not to close the window is a manipulation tactic
Fake case ID to seem legitimate
Foreign location (Russia) mentioned to create fear
explanation: This mimics Apple's visual style to trick Mac and iPhone users. Like the Microsoft version, it wants you to call a fake support number where scammers will try to get remote access to your device or trick you into paying for unnecessary 'security services.' Apple handles security through your Apple ID settings at appleid.apple.com and through their official Support app ‚Äî never through browser pop-ups with phone numbers.
howToSpot: Apple never shows security alerts in your browser. Real Apple security issues are handled through your Apple ID settings or the official Apple Support app. Close the browser window.

title: Fake 'You've Won' Prize Pop-up
subject: Congratulations! You've Been Selected!
body:
üéâ CONGRATULATIONS! üéâ

You are today's lucky visitor!

You have been selected to receive:
üéÅ A Brand New iPhone 16 Pro (Value: $1,199)

OR
üíµ A $1,000 Walmart Gift Card

This offer expires in: 3:47 (countdown timer)

To claim your prize, answer 3 simple questions:

[CLAIM MY PRIZE NOW]

‚≠ê "I can't believe I actually won!" ‚Äî Karen M.
‚≠ê "Got my gift card in 2 days!" ‚Äî Bob T.

Only 3 prizes remaining today!
redFlags: You can't 'win' a prize from a random website visit
Countdown timer creates artificial urgency
Fake testimonials from 'Karen M.' and 'Bob T.'
'3 prizes remaining' is a pressure tactic ‚Äî this is shown to everyone
Will ask for personal info and credit card for 'shipping'
No legitimate company gives away $1,199 phones to random visitors
explanation: Prize/reward pop-ups are designed to exploit excitement and urgency. After clicking 'Claim My Prize,' you'll be asked to answer fake survey questions, then provide your personal information and credit card for a small 'shipping fee' (usually $4.99-$9.99). The prize never arrives, but your credit card will be charged recurring monthly fees buried in the fine print. You'll also receive a flood of spam because your info is sold to other scammers.
howToSpot: You cannot win prizes from random website visits. Legitimate sweepstakes never ask for credit card information to claim prizes. If you didn't enter a contest, you can't have won one.

title: Fake Browser Update Notice
subject: Chrome Update Required
body:
Google Chrome ‚Äî Critical Update Required

Your version of Chrome is out of date and vulnerable to security threats.

Current Version: 98.0.4758.102
Latest Version: 122.0.6261.95

Security vulnerabilities detected:
- CVE-2024-1234 (Critical)
- CVE-2024-5678 (High)

[UPDATE CHROME NOW]

Skipping this update may leave your computer vulnerable to hackers.

Google Chrome Security Team
redFlags: Real Chrome updates happen automatically within the browser, not via pop-ups
Clicking 'Update' will download malware disguised as an update file
Real CVE numbers are used to seem legitimate but have nothing to do with the pop-up
Chrome never shows update prompts as webpage pop-ups
The download is malware, not a real update
explanation: Fake browser update pop-ups are a common way to distribute malware. The 'update' you download is actually malicious software that can steal passwords, install ransomware, or give hackers remote access to your computer. Real browser updates: (1) happen automatically in the background, (2) can be triggered from Chrome's menu (three dots > Help > About Chrome), and (3) NEVER ask you to download a file from a pop-up window.
howToSpot: Browsers update themselves automatically. Never download an 'update' from a pop-up. To update Chrome, go to Menu > Help > About Google Chrome. To update any software, go directly to the official website.

redFlags: Websites CANNOT scan your computer ‚Äî this is technically impossible
Fake threat names designed to sound scary and technical
'TotalSecure Pro' is not a real antivirus product
Claims your antivirus 'expired' without knowing what you have
Time-limited discount creates urgency
Payment will capture your credit card for recurring charges
explanation: A website cannot scan your computer for viruses ‚Äî this is a fundamental limitation of web browsers for security reasons. Any pop-up claiming to have found viruses on your computer is 100% fake, every time, no exceptions. These scam pop-ups either try to sell you fake antivirus software (stealing your credit card info) or trick you into downloading actual malware disguised as 'antivirus.' Use only legitimate antivirus software like Norton, Bitdefender, or Malwarebytes ‚Äî downloaded directly from their official websites.
howToSpot: Websites cannot scan your computer. Any browser pop-up claiming to have found viruses is always fake. Only trust antivirus software you installed yourself from a legitimate source.
